questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with dental caries is scheduled for a tooth extraction. Which of the following conditions does not require antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not routinely indicated for all cardiac conditions. Current guidelines recommend prophylaxis only for patients at the highest risk of adverse outcomes from IE.

These include:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or material
  • Left ventricular assist devices or implantable heart
  • Prior endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair
  • Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation.

Mitral valve prolapse, even with regurgitation, is no longer considered an indication for prophylactic antibiotics before dental procedures because the overall risk of IE in such patients is extremely low and potential adverse effects from unnecessary antibiotics outweigh benefits.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prophylaxis is limited to high-risk cardiac conditions only.
  • Mitral valve prolapse is not a current indication.

questions.text: Which of the following is specifically recommended for the prevention of chronic migraine but not episodic migraine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic migraine is defined as headache occurring ≥15 days per month for >3 months, with at least 8 days having migraine features.

Episodic migraine occurs on <15 days per month.

Onabotulinum toxin A is approved for the prevention of chronic migraine. It is not recommended for episodic migraine.

Mechanism is by Inhibiting peripheral release of nociceptive neurotransmitters (e.g., CGRP, substance P) and Reducing peripheral sensitization of trigeminal afferents.

Explanation of Other Options:

Propranolol (Option A): β-blocker effective for episodic migraine prevention but not specifically chronic migraine.

Divalproex sodium (Option B): Anticonvulsant used in episodic migraine prophylaxis.

Flunarizine (Option C): Calcium-channel blocker effective for episodic migraine but not approved for chronic migraine prophylaxis.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Onabotulinum toxin A → specific for chronic migraine prevention.
  • Episodic migraine prophylaxis: Propranolol, Divalproex, Topiramate, Flunarizine, Amitriptyline.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with a 2-week history of productive cough, fever, and progressive shortness of breath. Chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic alcoholics have high chances of aspiration pneumonia, which can progress to lung abscess formation due to aspiration of oropharyngeal anaerobes.

The radiographic finding of a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level confirms the diagnosis of lung abscess.

The drug of choice for anaerobic lung infections (especially aspiration-related) is Clindamycin, as it provides excellent coverage against Anaerobes (e.g., Peptostreptococcus, Bacteroides, Fusobacterium) and Microaerophilic streptococci

Alternative regimens may include β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam), but Clindamycin remains a first-line option, particularly for community-acquired aspiration pneumonia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ciprofloxacin (Option A): Primarily active against gram-negative bacilli but poor anaerobic coverage. Ineffective for aspiration pneumonia.

Cephalexin (Option C): First-generation cephalosporin with gram-positive coverage only and lacks anaerobic activity.

Vancomycin (Option D): Covers MRSA and gram-positive organisms only; no anaerobic or gram-negative coverage.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Clindamycin is the drug of choice for aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.
  • Always consider anaerobic coverage in alcoholics, seizure patients, or those with poor oral hygiene.
  • Radiographic hallmark: air-fluid level within a cavity in dependent lung segments.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with sudden-onset headache and diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage in her basal cisterns. Angiography shows a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, which is treated with endovascular coiling. She develops left-sided weakness 6 days later and became drowsy. Repeat head CT shows an infarct in right cerebral hemisphere, and her laboratory studies do not suggest infection or metabolic dysfunction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her new symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's clinical presentation of focal neurologic symptoms occurring roughly 6 days after aneurysm rupture is highly concerning for delayed cerebral ischemia secondary to vasospasm.

Pathophysiology: Vasospasm in the areteries due to direct effect of clotted blood and its breakdown and release of inflammatory mediators in the sub arachnoid space.

DCI occurs during 4-10 days post bleed.

Prevention and Management:

  • Nimodipine 60mg q4h (oral calcium-channel blocker) is routinely used to reduce ischemic complications after SAH.
  • Maintenance of euvolemia and adequate blood pressure is essential to preserve cerebral perfusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hydrocephalus (Option B): Can occur early or late but usually presents with headache, confusion, or gait disturbance usually not with neural deficit. Would appear on imaging

Re-bleeding (Option C): Typically occurs within 24 hours of the initial hemorrhage and presents with sudden neurologic deterioration, not gradual deficits days later. Would appear on imaging

SIADH (Option D): Causes hyponatremia, leading to lethargy or seizures, but not focal ischemic infarction.

Key takeaways :

Four major causes of delayed neurologic deficits:

  • Rerupture,
  • Hydrocephalus,
  • Delayed cerebral ischemia
  • hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 35 year old female being evaluated for dry eyes and dry mouth has the following laboratory findings: plasma sodium 139 meq/L, chloride 112 meq/L, bicarbonate 15 meq/L, and potassium 3.0 meq/L; urine studies show a pH of 6.0, sodium of 15 meq/L, potassium of 10 meq/L, and chloride of 12 meq/L. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the clinical picture the patient has Sjogren syndrome (dry eyes and dry mouth) and presents with:

  • Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (AG= 13)
  • Hypokalemia (K⁺ 3.0 mEq/L)
  • Urine pH > 5.5 despite systemic acidosis

In this patient the diagnosis is type I renal tubular acidosis, or distal RTA. This is a disorder in which the distal nephron does not lower pH normally (inadequate secretion of H+ ions). Leading to alkaline urine and impaired acid excretion

Associated with: Sjogren's Syndrome, Rheumatoid Arthritis, SLE.

  • Mixed type RTA was formerly known as type 3.

Explanation of Other Options:

Type II RTA (Option B):

  • Proximal bicarbonate wasting.
  • Urine can acidify (pH < 5.5) once serum HCO3- stabilizes at a lower level.
  • Seen in Fanconi syndrome or multiple myeloma.

Type III RTA (Option C):

  • not a standard classification in current literature.

Type IV RTA (Option D):

  • Due to aldosterone deficiency/resistance → hyperkalemia (unlike this patient's hypokalemia).
  • Common in diabetics or those on ACE inhibitors.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Type I (Distal) RTA: Urine pH > 5.5, hypokalemia, autoimmune association.
  • Type II (Proximal) RTA: Urine pH < 5.5, bicarbonate loss, variable potassium.
  • Type IV RTA: Hyperkalemia, aldosterone defect.
  • Evaluate for autoimmune causes (esp. Sjögren's).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with HIV presents with 4 weeks of diarrhea, fever, and weight loss.Which of the following tests makes the diagnosis of CMV colitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In immunocompromised patients (especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS, CD4 < 50 cells/μL), Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause colitis, characterized by fever, abdominal pain, watery or bloody diarrhea, and weight loss.

Serum CMV PCR has gained utility in solid organ and bone marrow transplant patients for following treatment response for invasive CMV infection.

However, in HIV-infected patients, CMV viremia correlates imprecisely with colitis. Also, because CMV is a latent-lytic herpesvirus, a positive serum PCR does not imply disease.

The definitive diagnosis of CMV colitis is made by colonoscopy with mucosal biopsy showing characteristic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic CMV inclusion bodies ("owl's eye" inclusions).

Explanation of other options:

Serum CMV PCR (Option A): Detects circulating CMV DNA but cannot distinguish latent or asymptomatic infection from active tissue disease.

Stool CMV antigen (Option C): Non-standard; unreliable and not validated for diagnosis of CMV colitis.

Stool CMV culture (Option D): Takes several weeks and lacks sensitivity; not recommended for clinical diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has best shown to reduce cardiovascular death in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In HFpEF, the ventricular muscle is stiff and noncompliant, leading to:

  • Impaired ventricular relaxation during diastole
  • Elevated left atrial and pulmonary venous pressures
  • Normal EF, but reduced stroke volume and cardiac output

Almost half of all HF occurs among patients with normal LVEF, often with diastolic dysfunction,

The only therapy shown to reduce cardiovascular death or HF hospitalization in this population is SGLT-2 inhibitors, specifically dapagliflozin or empagliflozin.

The mainstays of treating HF with preserved EF are :

  • SGLT-2 inhibitors
  • Diuretic therapy for fluid overload.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sacubitril + Valsartan (Option A): showed a trend toward reduced HF hospitalizations but no significant mortality benefit .

Metoprolol (Option B): β-blockers reduce mortality in HFrEF, but no proven survival benefit in HFpEF and is used mainly for rate control in atrial fibrillation or hypertension.

Spironolactone (Option C): modest reduction in HF hospitalization, but no reduction in CV death.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with symmetrical joint pain involving multiple joints, along with morning stiffness that improves gradually within an hour. Which of the following statements regarding the underlying condition is correct?
1. NSAIDS improve symptoms and have disease modifying activity
2. Absence of erosion on X-ray rules out diagnosis
3. Raised ESR and CRP
4. HLA DR4 is related to prognosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

RA is a chronic systemic autoimmune disease characterized by persistent, symmetric polyarthritis, primarily affecting small joints (MCP, PIP, wrist). It is more common in women (3:1 ratio), typically between ages 30-50.

Morning stiffness > 1 hour and symmetrical joint involvement are hallmark features.

1. NSAIDs improve symptoms and have disease-modifying activity - Incorrect statement

  • NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) provide symptomatic relief by reducing pain and inflammation.
  • They do not alter disease progression or prevent joint damage.

2. Absence of erosion on X-ray rules out diagnosis - Incorrect statement

  • Joint imaging is a valuable tool not only for diagnosing RA but also for tracking progression of any joint damage.
  • Plain x-ray is the most common imaging modality. Peri-articular osteopenia is the earliest X-ray finding.
  • Erosions appear only later.

3. Raised ESR and CRP - Correct statement

  • Inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are typically elevated in active disease.
  • These correlate with disease activity and are part of ACR/EULAR diagnostic criteria.

4.HLA-DR4 is related to prognosis - Correct statement

  • HLA-DR4 and HLA-DR1 alleles are associated with increased susceptibility and worse prognosis in RA.
  • Patients with these alleles tend to have more severe, erosive, and extra-articular disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male with sickle cell anemia presents with frequent episodes of painful vaso-occlusive crises. He has no history of stroke or organ damage. Which of the following medications is most effective in reducing the frequency of his pain episodes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene (valine replaces glutamic acid at position 6), producing HbS.
  • Under low oxygen tension, HbS polymerizes → sickling of RBCs → vaso-occlusion → tissue ischemia and painful crises.

Hydroxyurea - Disease-Modifying Therapy:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line and most effective agent for reducing painful vaso-occlusive episodes in sickle cell disease.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Increases production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which inhibits polymerization of HbS.
  • Reduces hemolysis, leukocyte count, and endothelial adhesion → improves microvascular blood flow.
  • Also raises total hemoglobin and MCV, and lowers frequency of acute chest syndrome and transfusions.

Treatment stratergy in sickle cell anemia:

  • Start with Hydroxyurea
  • Add Voxelotor if anemia persists
  • Add Crizanlizumab if vaso-occlusive crises continue
  • Use transfusions selectively
  • Consider stem cell transplant in severe or refractory cases with matched donor

Explanation of Other Options:

Methotrexate (Option A): Immunosuppressant used in autoimmune diseases (RA, psoriasis) and has no role in sickle cell disease.

Azathioprine (Option B): Immunomodulator used in autoimmune conditions and transplant and is not effective for vaso-occlusive prevention.

Eltrombopag (Option D): Thrombopoietin receptor agonist used for aplastic anemia and ITP and is unrelated to sickle cell crisis prevention.

choices.text: Selective degeneration of anterior horn cells resembling SMA
Increased risk of lymphoid and breast malignancies
Vitamin E deficiency as the primary underlying defect
Normal thymus with isolated cellular immune deficiency

questions.text: . A 7-year-old boy is brought with progressive gait imbalance and difficulty in speech. On examination, he has conjunctival vascular lesions, nystagmus, truncal ataxia, and distal sensory loss. His past history reveals recurrent lower respiratory tract infections. Laboratory evaluation shows decreased serum IgA and IgG2. Which of the following additional features is most consistent with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene (Ataxia Telangiectasia Mutated) on chromosome 11q22-23.
  • The ATM gene encodes a serine-threonine kinase involved in DNA double-strand break repair and cell-cycle checkpoint control.
  • Defective ATM → impaired DNA repair → chromosomal instability and increased malignancy risk
  • There is a high incidence of neoplasms of the lymphatic and reticuloendothelial system in patients with ataxia telangiectasia.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Selective degeneration of anterior horn cells resembling SMA (Option A):
    • Seen in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), which involves loss of motor neurons in the spinal cord leading to muscle weakness and atrophy.In contrast, A-T primarily involves cerebellar Purkinje cell degeneration, not anterior horn cells.
  • Vitamin E deficiency as the primary underlying defect (Option C):
    • Leads to ataxia, neuropathy, and areflexia, but no telangiectasias or immunodeficiency.It is a metabolic cause of spinocerebellar degeneration, not a DNA repair defect.
  • Normal thymus with isolated cellular immune deficiency (Option D):
    • In A-T, there is thymic hypoplasia and combined B-cell and T-cell dysfunction, not isolated T-cell deficiency.Also, humoral (IgA/IgG2) deficiency contributes to recurrent sinopulmonary infections.

questions.text: A patient with lupus nephritis and biopsy showing wire-loop lesions is started on induction therapy. Which of the following agents is/are recommended for induction treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wire-loop lesions on renal biopsy represent subendothelial immune complex deposits, characteristic of Class IV (Diffuse Proliferative) Lupus Nephritis.
This is the most severe and aggressive form of lupus nephritis, requiring prompt induction immunosuppressive therapy to control inflammation and prevent renal failure.

Induction therapy aims to achieve disease remission by rapidly suppressing immune activity.

Treatment strategies in lupus nephritis

  • Disease limited to renal mesangium - Excellent prognosis. No specific therapy
  • Mild class III - Steroids alone
  • Severe class III - Treat as class IV
  • Class IV
    Induction phase - High dose steroids + Cyclophosphamide/MMF
    Maintenance phase - MMF/Azathioprine
    Other approved add on's - Voclosporin/Belimumab
    Refractory cases - Rituximab
  • Class V - Immunosuppression, anticoagulation
  • Class VI - Dialysis/Renal transplantation

Explanation of other options:

High-dose glucocorticoids (Option A):Glucocorticoids alone are insufficient for induction therapy in Class III/IV lupus nephritis. They must be combined with an additional immunosuppressant (cyclophosphamide or MMF) for effective disease control.

Rituximab (Option C):Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used as a second-line or rescue therapy in refractory lupus nephritis. Not recommended as first-line induction agent.

Mycophenolate mofetil (Option D):Equally effective alternative to cyclophosphamide for induction, especially in Black or Hispanic patients and those desiring fertility preservation. Recommended by ACR and EULAR guidelines.

Key Takeaways

  • Wire-loop lesion = Class IV LN (Diffuse Proliferative).
  • Induction: High-dose glucocorticoids + cyclophosphamide or MMF.
  • Maintenance: MMF or azathioprine.
  • Rituximab: Reserved for refractory cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a core clinical characteristic of NMOSD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD) is an autoimmune, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by recurrent, severe attacks primarily involving the optic nerves, spinal cord, and specific brain regions rich in aquaporin-4 (AQP4) channels.The disease is mediated by anti-AQP4-IgG antibodies, which target astrocytes, leading to inflammation and demyelination.

Core clinical characteristics of NMOSD includes:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Acute myelitis
  • Area postrema syndrome:episode of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting
  • Acute brainstem syndrome
  • Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions
  • Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions

Key Takeaways:

  • Core features: Optic neuritis, acute myelitis, area postrema syndrome, brainstem, diencephalic, and cerebral syndromes.
  • Chronic myelitis is not typical; the disease manifests as acute relapses.
  • Anti-AQP4-IgG positivity confirms diagnosis and differentiates from multiple sclerosis

choices.text: Clinical signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis
Recent immobilization for more than 3 days

questions.text: According to the Wells prediction rule for pulmonary embolism, which of the following factors carries the highest likelihood of PE?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Wells clinical prediction rule stratifies the probability of pulmonary embolism (PE) based on seven clinical variables, each assigned a point value.
The factor carrying the highest weight is "Clinical signs and symptoms of DVT", which is assigned 3 points

INTERPRETATION

Score >6.0-High

Score 2.0-6.0-Intermediate

Score <2.0-Low

questions.text: Which of the following components of the jugular venous pulse corresponds with the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The jugular venous pulse (JVP) reflects right atrial pressure changes transmitted via the internal jugular vein.
During the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, the tricuspid valve closes and the right ventricle contracts against a closed valve, causing a brief bulging of the valve back into the right atrium.
This results in a small upward deflection known as the c wave in the JVP.


Key Takeaways:

  • c wave = isovolumetric contraction of the right ventricle.
  • a, c, v waves are upward deflections, while x, y descents are downward slopes.
  • JVP tracing provides insight into right atrial pressure dynamics and valvular events.

questions.text: Given below are the Contrast enhanced MRI Brain sequence and Diffusion weighted MRI sequence of a patient with intracranial space occupying lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An intracranial abscess typically presents as a ring-enhancing lesion on contrast-enhanced MRI with central diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI).

The differential diagnosis of ring enhancing lesions include ;

  • Metastasis
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Tuberculoma
  • Lymphoma
  • Subacute infarct
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Radiation necrosis
  • Demyelination
  • Resolving hematoma

Ring enhancing lesion with diffusion restriction is more likely to occur in cerebral abscess.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infarct (Option B):

Infarcts may show restricted diffusion early, but they lack ring enhancement and have a vascular distribution pattern. No smooth capsule formation.

Glioma (Option C):

Typically shows heterogeneous, irregular enhancement, not smooth or thin. The central necrotic area does not restrict diffusion, and surrounding edema is more infiltrative.

Tuberculoma (Option D):

Can mimic an abscess but usually shows irregular or nodular ring enhancement and no central diffusion restriction.
On T2-weighted MRI, may show a hypointense rim (due to caseous necrosis) and may demonstrate MR spectroscopy lipid peak.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Brain abscess: Smooth ring enhancement + diffusion restriction (central DWI bright signal).
  • Tumor necrosis: Irregular ring, no central restriction.
  • Tuberculoma: Irregular ring, lipid peak on spectroscopy, no restricted diffusion.
  • Infarct: Vascular territory, early DWI restriction, no capsule.

questions.text: Among the following infections, the least common cause of AV block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atrioventricular (AV) block may occur due to infections that directly or indirectly damage the cardiac conduction system, myocardium, or endocardium.

Among the listed infections, HIV infection is the least common cause of AV block.

Although HIV can lead to various cardiac complications - such as pericardial effusion, dilated cardiomyopathy, infective endocarditis, and drug-induced conduction abnormalities - a primary AV block directly caused by HIV infection is rare.

When AV block occurs in HIV patients, it is usually secondary to opportunistic infections (e.g., Toxoplasma gondii, Cytomegalovirus) or drug toxicity (e.g., zidovudine, protease inhibitors), not HIV itself.

Infectious causes of AV block includes ;

  • Lyme carditis
  • Bacterial endocarditis with perivalvular abscess
  • Viral myocarditis
  • Chaga's disease
  • Toxoplasmosis

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Common infectious causes of AV block: Lyme disease, Chaga's disease, bacterial endocarditi, viral myocarditis, toxoplasmosis
  • HIV: Rarely causes AV block directly and typically is a secondary effect.

choices.text: Best heard in sitting and leaning forward position

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Hamman's sign is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hamman's sign is a crunching, rasping, or clicking sound heard synchronously with the heartbeat, typically over the precordium, and is caused by pneumomediastinum.It results from the heart beating against air-filled tissues in the mediastinum.

The sound is often described as a "mediastinal crunch", and may vary with body position or respiration.

It is best heard in the left lateral decubitus position (not sitting and leaning forward), particularly during expiration.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Hamman's sign: Crunching sound with each heartbeat, due to pneumomediastinum.
  • Best heard: Left lateral decubitus position.
  • Differentiation: Unlike pericardial rub (respiratory), Hamman's sign follows cardiac rhythm.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is used in the treatment of refractory ITP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Refractory ITP refers to persistent thrombocytopenia and bleeding despite standard first-line therapy (glucocorticoids, IV immunoglobulin, or splenectomy).

In such cases, thrombopoietin receptor agonists (TPO-RAs) like Romiplostim and Eltrombopag are used to stimulate platelet production.

Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist, leading to increased platelet production.

Explanation of Other Options:

Idarucizumab (Option A): A specific antidote for dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) used to reverse its anticoagulant effect in major bleeding or emergency surgery. It has no role in ITP management.

Anakinra (Option C): An IL-1 receptor antagonist used in rheumatoid arthritis and autoinflammatory syndromes such as Still's disease.Not used in ITP.

Tofacitinib (Option D): A JAK inhibitor used in rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis, and other autoimmune conditions, but not indicated for ITP.

Key Takeaways:

  • First-line ITP treatment: Corticosteroids, IVIG.
  • Refractory ITP: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag (TPO agonists).
  • Alternative therapies: Rituximab, splenectomy.
  • Mechanism: Thrombopoietin receptor agonist, leading to increased platelet production

questions.text: Which of the following causes hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Liddle syndrome is a autosomal dominant disorder characterized by early-onset hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, due to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in the collecting ducts of the kidney.

  • Caused by gain-of-function mutations in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) located on the collecting duct principal cells.
  • This leads to excessive sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, mimicking the effects of hyperaldosteronism but with low renin and low aldosterone
  • The result is hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Treatment:

  • Amiloride or triamterene (ENaC blockers) are effective treatments.
  • Spironolactone is ineffective since aldosterone is already suppressed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gitelman syndrome (Option B): Defect in the Na⁺-Cl⁻ cotransporter of the distal convoluted tubule. Gitelman syndrome causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but with normal or low blood pressure.

Gordon syndrome (Option C): Gordon syndrome causes hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis with hypertension.

Bartter syndrome (Option D): Bartter syndrome causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but usually with normal or low blood pressure.

Key Takeaways (Optional):

  • Liddle syndrome: Hypertension + hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis + low renin/aldosterone.
  • Gitelman/Bartter: Hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis + normal BP.
  • Gordon: Hyperkalemia + metabolic acidosis + hypertension.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male is referred for further management of suspected ankylosing spondylitis. He was told he had abnormality in radiograph (see image). He emphatically denies stiffness, pain, or enthesopathy. His examination shows slightly limited spine flexion and normal chest expansion. Inflammatory markers are not elevated and he had no history of ocular disease or adolescent back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) is a non-inflammatory disorder characterized by calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments, particularly the anterior longitudinal ligament and usually occurs in the middle age

Radiographic features (as seen in the image):

  • Ligamentous calcification gives the appearance of "flowing wax" on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae.
  • Intervertebral disk spaces are preserved,
  • Sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal

These features help to differentiate them from other diseases.

Clinical features:

  • Usually occurs in elderly men.
  • No significant back pain, stiffness, or elevated inflammatory markers.
  • May be associated with metabolic conditions such as type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, and hyperinsulinemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Reactive arthritis (Option A): Post-infectious arthritis following genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection. Usually affects younger men, with asymmetric oligoarthritis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Does not cause diffuse flowing ossification seen in DISH.

Psoriatic arthritis (Option C): Occurs in patients with psoriasis.Involves asymmetric sacroiliitis, syndesmophytes, and peripheral arthritis.Radiographic findings differ - coarse, irregular syndesmophytes, not smooth flowing ossification.

Pseudogout (Option D): Due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Affects peripheral joints (knees, wrists), not typically associated with large anterior spinal ossification patterns. No flowing ligamentous calcifications.
